results.description:
Join other beginning golfers at Pine Ridge in a fun and relaxed evening of golf. 

$20.50 includes cart and as much golf as you can play!    

$17 if you like to walk.

You must be signed up in order to receive this rate.

One of our coaches from the Baltimore Golf Academy will be your host for these Wed. evening events.  He will be on hand to answer questions, help new players with speed of play and on course management.

Who should attend? This Meet Up is for new to high handicap players.  You should have some lesson experience.  It is not a golf lesson on how to swing the club--but an on the course experience.  It will be a relaxed atmosphere and everyone supports one another.

If you are a better player, the Friday evening Meet Up may suit you better.

 Where to meet: Meet up at the pro shop. Let the cashier know you are a member of the Baltimore Golf Meet Up Group.  Pay your green fees.  Go to starter and he will pair you up with other people in the group.

 Various formats of play include:

Scramble- all players hit shot then play from best ball of group

Alternate Shot-Two player team event

Best ball of Four--pretty obvious!

Stroke Play--you play your own ball

Beginner Rules:

Double Par--once you reach double par you can pick up

Improved Lies- If you decide you want to place your ball in a better place, feel free to do so as long as it is not closer to the hole

No whining!  No one want to play with a whiner.

Keep up with the group ahead of you.

Have fun!  That's actually the number one rule.
results.name: Twilight Golf at Pine Ridge for Beginner Golfers

results.description:
Patapsco is strictly intermediate terrain including log overs (up to 3' tall, and individual logs up to 10"), rocks, stream crossings, very steep climbs, root covered climbs, 12" wide trails, and in general pretty technical.  It's not the water shed, but it is demanding.  Please understand this is an intermediate ride due to this terrain.

Waiver: Mountain biking is a risky sport, By signing up for this meetup you are agreeing to our waiver located here: http://www.meetup.com/MVD-Mountain-Bikers/pages/Standard_Waiver_for_Meetup_Rides/


With the days getting longer we will probably not need lights, but it may be a good idea to have one with you in case we get delayed on the trails.  As the days get longer so will the ride!


Where/Directions: Rockburn Elementary School

What time: Meet between 5:45 and 6:00 at parking lot. Wheels rolling by 6:00. We will not wait past 6:00.  

Pace: Pace will be Intermediate, approx. 6.5 to 7 mph. Appropriate for average to riders, but not for beginners, or people who are not riding at least once a week.  Attitude is laid-back and friendly, but please ensure you can handle the pace and length of this ride before committing. This is a no-drop ride, i.e., we wait up for everyone at intersections. (Note: if you don’t want to wait up for slower riders, this is NOT the ride for you, but please also survey your current fitness, as no one likes to be the one person holding up a larger group).  Please also note Ptap rides tend to be about 1 mph slower than Rosy, or Fairland, due terrain.  

Terrain: Ranges from Easy to Difficult. Most trails are in great shape, but plan on some mud spots. There are a few very steep climbs, rocks and technical sections, log overs (up to 10" logs, and 3' stacks), tight single track (12" wide in spots), and a stream crossing or two.  A strong/advanced rider will be able to clean most sections, others will need to get off of their bikes in spots.  This is a friendly ride, so we will wait up for everyone, just be advised that the terrain can be somewhat difficult in places.  This is a video edit I made from last fall through winter.  We won't hit all of this terrain, but gives you a feel for Patapsco:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-DLM17FYo3M

Distance: With days getting longer we will be minimally getting 10 miles, and if conditions and light allow, we will push towards 20.  Exact route will change depending on group dynamics, trail conditions, daylight, etc.  I will typically have route planned in my head at the beginning of the ride, but will modify as needed to get us back at a reasonable time.  

Duration: I shoot to have us back before it gets dark (so 2 to 3 hours as the days get longer).  This can change with mechanical issues, and group dynamics though.  As this is a weekday ride, the stops will be just long enough for the last rider to catch their breath.  Note: wheels roll at stated time, so please don’t be late.

Bring: Helmet (required), water (as much as you can carry), spare tube/patch kit, pump/CO2, multi-tool, I.D., emergency contact info where it can be easily located on your person, and a good attitude, as this ride is as much about camaraderie as it is about riding. Take a look at your bike and make sure it is in good working condition (Ptap will take its toll on the bike).  Bring a light, as you might need it.  There are ton of acceptable lights under $20 on Amazon right now.  Just look for a T6 Cree LED Bike light, with minimially 1000 lumens.  Here is a link to one: Cheap 1000 lumen bike light<a href="http://www.amazon.com/dp/B006QQX3C4/ref=wl_it_dp_o_pC_nS_ttl?_encoding=UTF8&colid=3FJIG6WZ09712&coliid=I15GIMB04YOTYI"></a>

Weather: Shine Only (there will undoubtedly be some mud, but no ride if it’s raining or the trails are too muddy). Protect our trails and don’t ride them when they’re fragile. There may be days where I make a last minute call, so watch this page and our Facebook group on days where there is a chance of rain.

Ride Organizer(s): Craig P.


Craig P, 443-8four5-threesix89; skibum616 at yahoo dot com
results.how_to_find_us: We will be in the School Parking Lot (Don't park past the park gates, as if we come back after dark, you might not be able to get out).  Look for bikes and a bald guy with his grey Motobecane.  That's me.
results.name: Hump Day at Patapsco

results.description:
The Wednesday Night Paddler
RESCUE PRACTICE

Just so everyone is clear, this is all about rescues and there will be no regular paddling.  We will not have our usual social half hour off the water either.  You'll pay $50 to $100 per class for a chance to fall out of your boat elsewhere.  This one is totally free if you have your own boat and only $25.00 if you don't.

One of the greatest things to happen at a paddle a few years ago was when a couple of our members were able to handle a rescue situation entirely on their own while on one of our weekend paddles thanks to the fact they attended one of these sessions.

Everyone who paddles a kayak needs to know how to get back in it on their own when they fall out too far from shore.  The rescue practice sessions are designed to help you learn to do that.

Don't worry, no one who comes will have to do anything other than watch various types of self and assisted rescues.  Although just watching sort of defeats the purpose of the night, even watching will have you better prepared WHEN not IF you need to use these techniques.  If you paddle a kayak, you are going to fall in.  Even the best of us do from time to time.  Absolutely nothing makes me laugh harder than hearing that you just don't fall in or haven't in a long time.  Are you ready for it when it happens to you?  Bring a paddle float and bilge pump if you have them but we'll have extras if you don't. Bring a spray skirt if you have one.

We did the last one of these at Daniels Dam on the Patapsco and it actually turned out pretty well at that location so we'll be at Daniels again.  The group is too big for much one one one instruction so we will start off with a couple demonstrations and then break off into groups of two or three to try the rescues.  The last couple of times everyone was too busy practicing to bother stopping to socialize so we will suspend the social hour for this session.

Rescues are something that all kayakers need to practice a few times a season whether you've done them before or not.  They need to be something you do instinctively without thinking.  IF YOU ARE NOT PRACTICING YOUR RESCUES A FEW TIMES A SEASON YOU REALLY SHOULD NOT BE PADDLING A KAYAK.

There are rental boats available for this paddle at a price of $25.00 for the evening delivered to the put in with paddle and PFD. You can request a rental during the RSVP process.
results.name: The Wednesday Night Paddler - RESCUE PRACTICE

*** If you are attending this practice, please don't forget to sign up on our website by clicking the "Sign Up" link at the top. ***

The BDBC open practices occur every Wednesday from 6:15 to 7:30 PM and Saturday mornings from 8:30 to 9:30. For those of you that have never participated in dragon boating before, here are a few handy things to know to make your experience more enjoyable:


- The club has never flipped a boat during practice so the odds of you going completely into the water are very low but please keep in mind that there can be a significant amount of splashing on board. Chances are good that you will get a bit wet while we're out there so you should dress accordingly. Wear clothes that you won't mind getting wet in.

- As far as footwear goes, some people like to paddle barefoot, some like to wear flip flops and others like water shoes of some sort. Sneakers and shoes like that are usually a bad idea since they can get pretty wet and uncomfortable pretty quickly. - Although the club normally tries to have a cooler available with bottled water, it's not a bad idea to bring a bottle with you to practice to take on the boat. During the summer months especially, it can get pretty warm out there and we like to hydrate regularly.

- The seats on the boat are not the softest in the world and your butt will most likely be a bit sore after practice. To soften the seat a bit, it is recommended that you bring some sort of pad. There are many different options that our club members use and some of the most popular are gardening knee pads and folded up bath mats. A bunched up towel will suffice as well. - Other handy items that you may want to bring with you are sunglasses, sunscreen, gloves and a hat.

- Life jackets and paddles are provided to everyone.

- There is not room on the boat to bring much else with you so please leave everything in your car/on land.

- There is a secure waterproof bag available to collect everyone's car keys when we get on the boat.

- The point of our open practices, is to get people familiar with the sport of dragon boating while demonstrating proper technique and timing. Our coaches are excellent at explaining the mechanics of paddling a dragon boat and working towards the ultimate goal of having all twenty paddlers working as a single unit to move as efficiently through the water as possible, all while having a whole lot of fun! More information can be found at <a>www.baltimoredragonboatclub.com.</a> Hope to see you there!

results.description:
For 8 successive Wednesdays, there is a guided history tour on the Torrey C. Brown Rail Trail, which I think most of us know as the NCR Trail. Each tour will cover the specific history of both the trail and the surrounding area of the stated location. Each tour starts at the indicated NCR stop and "bites off" roughly 10 miles for that evening. What a great way to eventually experience the entire trail in bite size portions. The Maryland Park Service volunteer in Monkton couldn't stop praising this series when I asked her about it. The leader is a "local" who is very passionate about the history of his "hometown". There is no charge.

Just to be VERY clear. This event(s) is open to the general public; it is not dedicated to this Meetup group. We are not the ones in charge of the start time; the Guide is. So please do not be late. We can't ask him to wait.

Also, Here's a link to the DNR website which gives directions to each of the 8 locations (also with a nice map of the Trail).

http://www.dnr.state.md.us/greenways/ncrt_trail.html

The "kick off" tour is on June 3 at Paper Mill Rd


6-03 - PAPER MILL

6-10 - BENTLEY SPRINGS

6-17 - MONKTON

6-24 - WHITE HALL

7-01 - FREELAND

7-08 - SPARKS

7-15 - PARKTON

7-22 - PHOENIX


All rides begin 6:30 P.M. (weather permitting).

results.description:
As everyone has enjoyed the brunches and happy hours, I figured why not explore some of the areas best places to grab dinner?  So, here we are now with bimonthly dinners!.  We'll explore a different Baltimore area restaurant every other month and have more intimate groups as with the brunches.  This will allow everyone a chance to get to know others in the group on a smaller scale. Anyone with suggestions of places around the city, feel free to send me a message.  I'd love this to be a fun experience for all of us.

For our first stop, we'll visit one of my absolute favorites and one of Baltimore's most popular spots - Abbey Burger Bistro. 

Here's an intro about them from their website...

The Abbey Burger Bistro is located in the heart of Baltimore's Federal Hill neighborhood. Tucked away at 1041 Marshall St (off Cross St, directly across from the market), the Abbey offers an enticing selection of flavors for any burger palate. If you're feeling creative, you can build your own, or simply choose one of the tested and proven classics and leave it to the chef. The Abbey also features a wide selection of local, domestic, and imported beers and micro-brews, as well as an expansive bar. The Abbey is also a destination for sports fans. With twelve screens spread across two floors of bars, there is plenty of seating on game day.

Find out more about them on urbanspoon or on their website.  

Just a couple less fun notes:

• Please keep your RSVP updated and accurate.  Let's be mindful that many times there is a wait list for events.  If a spot is held for someone that does not attend the event, it prevents others who wanted to attend the chance to come out and have a good time with us.  We would love for all those who are able and interested to have the chance to meet other FUN PEOPLE in the group :). Also, the organizers put a significant amount of time into setting up events.  In order for us to continue having a great time organizing these, its important that our reservations at restaurants and other places hold some weight. I know things will happen from time to time, but please take the 5 seconds to update your RSVP if your plans change. Okay, all done :)

results.description:
A friend recently introduced me to this trail and it is one of my favorite local trails. There are a lot of smaller hills so you get a nice work out. There are some cool features like man-made valleys left over from train tracks. And the entire hike is along the river so there are many views of the winding Little Gunpowder River.

Meet at the Guyton/Bottom Rd Parking lot. Hike the trail north of the river to Pleasantville rd, and then back on the trail south of the river. Moderate Hike Approximately 5 miles. Please bring a head lamp. There is a good chance we won't finish before it is too dark to hike safely without light.

Please bring plenty of water. 1 Liter is recommended. The trail is dirt, rocks, roots, and some mud. Plan for appropriate footwear.

We will step off at 6:45PM.

Dogs are welcome on this hike but they must be well behaved and on lead at all times.

Long hiking pants are highly recommended!

The group usually grabs a drink afterward at Gunpowder lodge or another nearby restaurant. Group decides.
results.name: Evening/Night Hike along Little Gunpowder River

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

A group walk on the paved trail at Riverfront Park in Old Town Laurel.


Starting at the parking lot at the dead-end of Main Street, walking the length of the trail and returning to the parking lot.   Total distance is about 2.5 miles round trip.

Bring:
Water and dog waste-pick up bags

Trail is paved. However there is a lot of grassy area along the trail for dogs to sniff.


Meet at the parking lot PAST the Laurel Municipal Pool at the dead-end of Main Street, near the Laurel Museum. PAST 9th street, Main Street dead-ends into a parking lot which is beyond the swimming pool. We're NOT meeting at the swimming pool parking lot!

Use 817 MAIN ST, LAUREL, MD 20707 in your GPS.  That will get you to the Laurel Historical Museum.  From there, you are about 100 yards away from where the walk begins.   


Information about Riverfront Park:
Riverfront Park, one of the City's most beautiful parks, is a 30.2 acre park that parallels the scenic Patuxent River from the historic dam ruins to U.S. Route 1. The park is located adjacent to Laurel Municipal Pool and the Laurel Museum.

The Park features three picnic pavilions, a waterless restroom structure, parking, paved walking/biking paths, tot lot, picnic tables and grills throughout the park, open play areas, scenic wetland area and historic dam ruins .

results.description:
Please join us at Mr. Chan for great food and stimulating conversation! Our group welcomes anyone who is interested in talking about any aspect of the vegan or veg lifestyle, including health, food preparation, compassion for animals, spirituality, activism, ecology, and more.

Our meetings have been fun, lively, and supportive. Mr. Chan has a wonderful selection of vegan menu options, probably the most of any Baltimore area restaurant.  Mr. Chan is located on 1000 Reisterstown Road, across the street from the Pikes Theater. There is often street parking available. And there is free parking behind the restaurant, and a public parking area adjacent to that lot.

Meetup attendees get an opportunity each month to tell us a little about themselves: where they are from; what got them interested in the veg/vegan lifestyle; their personal interests; success stories; or a chance to get some answers to questions with regard to diet and lifestyle.

And please check out the monthly Earthsave Veg Dinner Series events that are normally held on the last Saturday from 6-8 pm at Towson Presbyterian Church, 400 Chesapeake Ave in Towson. The dinners are vegan and often attract a group of 40-70 attendees.  For more information, see http://earthsavebaltimore.org/. Hope to see you there!

You may also want to check out the Baltimore Vegetarian Meetup group, which is very similar to this one, but meets on the first Sunday, at 12.30 pm, at Mango Grove in Columbia. To register for those meetings, go to http://vegetarian.meetup.com/9 We think you will enjoy the great food and atmosphere, like-minded people, and lively, casual conversation. Hope to see you soon! Meetup.com charges each group organizer for the great services they provide. A donation of $1 per meeting will help cover these costs and would be appreciated. Thanks.

CONNECT with like-minded local people for discussion and support on Facebook by joining Earthsave Baltimore group athttps://www.facebook.com/groups/EarthsaveBaltimore/ We also host a very popular and active global Facebook group called Earth Friendly Food Choices. Join us at https://www.facebook.com/groups/103906449752363/

Thanks so much! Hope to see you soon!

results.description:
Schedule:

7:00-7:10: Eat pizza and grab drinks. 
7:10-7:30: Quick introductions. 
7:30-8:00: Presentation 
8:00-whatever: Questions, chats, trying things out.

Presentation:

Erik Bray will be presenting on anonymous code blocks in Python. Anonymous code blocks are a frequently requested feature in the Python language, particularly anonymous blocks with granular execution control. Our presenter will be discussing a "hack" he created [1] which is a potentially useful stepping stone to implementing this feature. Topics covered will include context managers, stack frame inspection, custom stack trace functions, python bytecode disassembly and interpretation as well as the general topic of anonymous blocks. Erik is a software developer at the Space Telescope Science Institute.


https://gist.github.com/embray/f95d9cbe677542ce19a1
results.how_to_find_us: Take the elevators to the third floor.

results.description:
What can Hola! Toastmasters do for you?

- Do you want to look and feel more confident when you speak?

- Do you want to learn how to think and speak on your feet?

- Would you like to meet fun and interesting people?

- Would you like to be a better leader, influence people, and possibly even get faster promotions?

Hola! Toastmasters uses a proven program that encourages small steps and learning-by-doing to help you become the speaker and leader you want to be. Each Toastmasters meeting gives speakers an opportunity to give prepared speeches, practice impromptu speaking, receive supportive and useful feedback, and hone their interpersonal and communication skills.

We usually have 20-30 people attend each Toastmasters meeting, and it's always lively and fun!

WHEN: 1st and 3rd Tuesdays of every month

results.description:
Thursday will be 73 degrees and cloudy. Let's start early (at 9:00 a.m.) before it gets to be "Feels Like 82" a couple hours later. There is a 25% chance of showers, but we'll cancel out if there is outright rain. Great day for a doggy walk around the lake :)  We can do two laps to make it 3 miles, or you can bail out after the 1.5 mile loop.

Please look carefully at the instructions and map below to find out where to park and meet for the walk!

Lake Kittamaqundi, the downtown heart of Columbia. For many years, the path only went only part-way around the lake. But this fall, the Columbia Association completed the circuit and we can now walk around the entire lake along a new paved path!

This walk is very flat, only one gentle hill, and 1.5 miles around. We'll pass by the People Tree, the lakefront stage, and long-established Columbia restaurants like Clyde's and Tomato Palace.


You will basically head for the new Whole Foods of Columbia (added in Fall 2014), across from the Columbia Mall. However, we will park and meet in the lower lot, down the hill, and to the right of Whole Foods (as you look at it from the front.) This is actually the parking lot for the new Haven on the Lake spa. Please park in the area furthest from the spa entrance, as shown on the map below, so that we are closest to the trail and won't get in the way of the spa clients.


Please arrive early, to allow the dogs time to sniff and form their pack. We will leave on time.  If you can't make it please change your RSVP promptly, or leave a comment.  We'll turn to the right on the trail so you'll know where to find us if you arrive late.  


Please bring water for your dogs.  We'll have drinking stops and take pictures at a couple of places, and we'll all have fun! 


Columbia Dogs on the Go provides a way for friendly people with friendly dogs to meet people with similar interests on a voluntary basis. By replying "Yes" to this RSVP and attending this event, you acknowledge that: 

•  You are responsible for your own safety and the safety of your dogs and any guests. 

•  Your dogs are current on their vaccinations.

•  Your dogs will be kept on a 6-foot fixed leash (non-retractable) and under your control at the Meetup.

•  You will clean up after your dogs at the Meetup.

•  You will update your RSVP if your plans change.

•  You understand that the Meetup ends when the walk ends. (If you choose to meet other members at a restaurant, dog park, or other location, it is on your own time and not part of the Meetup event.)

 Looking forward to seeing everyone again!

If you are a solo founder in need of a partner in crime, this “How to Find the Perfect Startup Co-Founder” webinar will teach you how to find a business partner who compliments your talents and shares a similar vision. Hosted by Adeo Ressi (Founder & CEO of the Founder Institute, 9X entrepreneur, and Managing Director of Expansive Ventures), this event will also feature Dan Arkind (CEO & Co-Founder of JobScore, and Recruitment Consultant & Coach, Startup Advisor) and Jessica Alter (Founder and CEO of FounderDating). -----

This is a free, online event that you can watch and participate in from your computer. To get access and receive the link to this private event, you must register at http://bit.ly/CoFounder-Webinar. This is a requirement because we are using GoToWebinar to host this online event.

-----

On this webinar you will learn:

- How to scope your needs and find a business partner with skill sets you may be lacking.

- How to examine common goals and personality traits that better match your own.

- How to interview candidates, and what to look for in prior experience.

- Where to find the best talent and decide how many cofounders you’ll need.

- How to split tasks and equity

----

To get access and receive the link to this private event, you must register at http://bit.ly/CoFounder-Webinar. This is a requirement because we are using GoToWebinar to host this online event. ----

This webinar will be held in English, and will last approximately 1 hour. For more information on Founder Institute Webinars, visit http://fi.co/webinars.

Baltimore SharePoint is hosting Toby McGrail as he will deliver an informative session on Common SharePoint Errors and how to troubleshoot and resolve them. 

The Baltimore SharePoint User's Group meets every third Thursday of the week at the ProObject building in Hanover, MD. 7467 Ridge Road, Hanover, MD

Thanks for your continued support of BSPUG Shadeed Eleazer

Session Topic Correlation or Bust: Demystifying Common SharePoint Errors

So we all have seen a Correlation ID or some other sort of error message as a Power User, Administrator, Business Analyst so where do we go now?

What you Will Learn

• Tips, hints, tools and other information on how to resolve common issues with SharePoint 2010, 2013 and Server Side Issues. 

• How to Resolve these common issues that plague SharePoint environments

•Best practices on configuration settings to monitor SharePoint errors 

• Server Side tools to help you do your job more effectively

Meet the Speaker
Toby McGrail is a Senior Software Engineer with experience in SharePoint 2003, 2007,2010 ,and 2013. He has been working in IT since 1995 and extensively with SharePoint since 2006. He specializes in the Administrative and Architecture side of the house. Toby has provided many applications within SharePoint. Not only OOB Solutions but Custom Built Applications. He has worked with many clients but mostly in the Federal Space. Toby has a grasp in what many Administrators face on a day to day basis. Twitter sptoby1  Event Details

Food and beverages will be served 

Parking is free and plenty of space is available

results.description:
Our SHR group always enjoys attending music events at the Annapolis Maritime Museum in Eastport. It's a nice facility with a scenic outdoor location on Back Creek, its own beach, a beautiful pier, a nautical museum, and good restrooms. 

This event is one of the Museum's weekly Tides & Tunes Summer Concerts featuring a variety of bands from around this area. The featured group this week is the Eastport Oyster Boys, a popular local band that plays a mix of good time tunes at many events in Eastport. They're always fun and entertaining.

Although the concerts are technically free, a $10 donation is expected. That's a fair price for having a relaxing evening of good music and a nice social vibe by the water. Beer, wine, mixed drinks, and food are available for sale. No coolers are allowed, but be sure to bring your folding chair or blanket.

The summer concert series on Thursday evenings is an excellent reason to get out of the house and have some FUN. We'll plan to meet around 6:00 pm to find a place to sit and mingle before the concert starts at 7:00 pm. Look for us having a good time or call Jake at[masked]-8435. I can't always answer my phone at events, but you can try.

In case of inclement weather, the concerts will be canceled with a notice posted on the museum's website. For more information and directions visit www.amaritime.org or call the museum staff at[masked]-0104.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Jake's neon white hair in the festival area or call me at 703-798-8435
results.name: Eastport Oyster Boys at the Annapolis Maritime Museum

results.description:
About the Series and Inspiration:

In my 10 years of experience in spirituality, I have run the gamut. I’ve gone to conventions, crystal shows, spiritual workshops, yoga retreats, angel classes, healing circles and more reiki shares than you can shake a stick at. All of it has led me to believe that 90% of healers and spiritualists of this age are lost. Not lost as in they do not know what to do, many have pretty spot-on intuition, but lost as in they do not know how healing works. They do not understand the intricate of the art. The universal language is misunderstood, is a non-thought, intention and expectation become something that must be said aloud before the healing begins and often times fail to understand the limits of their own modalities. The classes in this series are designed to fill the cracks in the foundation. We’ll be dedicating classes to concepts such as nonthought, karma, the universal language, how to heal ailments hard-written into the body versus those that are not and many more.

The Universal Language:

  As healers, I cannot stress enough how important it is to be able to understand the universe when it tries to communicate with us. However, many of us do not know how to communicate with it, or worse, we believe the universe is speaking to us when in actuality it is our biological systems.

Newsflash to us! The Universe doesn’t speak English. If it did, people would be traveling to America, England and Australia to find spirituality, rather than places like India, Nepal and Tibet. Then, what language does it speak? It is one that is felt, rather than spoken aloud. Our minds translate it so often that we never think to acknowledge that feeling until it has already become a word. If you have ever had a moment wherein you were completely speechless, because there was no word to describe what just happened, this is the reason. The core concept is simple: the Universal Language is limitless and man-made languages are limited. The best way to jumpstart your healing abilities is to learn to speak this language so the universe will be able to comprehend your intentions. They’ll come across with less of an accent, and you’ll be able to clearly comprehend the responses you receive.

What will you be able to do after this class?


• Translate signs of the universe, such as aura/auric colors, visions and dreams

• Know when messages are divine messages and messages from the body or ego

• Transmit and receive basic codes, feelings and messages

• Get a truer sense in knowing what needs to be healed

• Expand your healing tool kit so that each session can have more customization

Required Experience Healing: None!

These classes will be geared towards advanced healers, so at least a few years of experience with energetic healing arts, such as reiki, seichim, qigong or crystal work will provide a great foundation to understand the concepts discussed. However, the healing secrets exposed in this class series will be explained in such a way that even those with little to no basic knowledge of energy, healing or spirituality will be able to understand.

Fee per person: $5; cash only upon arrival (no credit card or checks)
Minimum number of registrants: 5
For more info: Contact Colton Parker: [masked] or
call: <a>(301)[masked]</a>

***Night of this event, receptionist not available to answer calls in the evenings and messages will be returned the next day.

---About Colton:   https://youtu.be/knXQVhhXZPU 

Colton is a spiritual-realist. He ascribes to no one modality of spirituality, rather allows as many as possible shape and shift his own consciousness, guiding him to his own inner truth. He has a Bachelor’s degree in Operations Management with a minor in Japanese, which have heavily affected his spiritual path. He also has a strong background in reiki, possessing a master-teacher certification for Usui Reiki (1-4 and 5-18), Kundalini Reiki, Lighterian Reiki, Karunaki, Shamballa (multidimensional healing or MDH) and Ayurvedic Reiki. He prides himself on being a teacher not only to his formal students but also to friends and family, teaching even as they realize not how they are being taught. As a teacher, Colton’s uniqueness lies in his clarity of expression, his ability to see connections overlooked by others, and the shifted state he enters when teaching a class. His spiritual growth was most affected by his 10+ years of Reiki and Crystal experiences, his current pursuit of kundalini yoga teaching certification, his study of quantum physics, the eight months he spent in Japan, as well as his own spiritual teachers.

Please join us at our monthly Third-Thursday meetup.  This month we will discussing Chakras.

Chakras are energy points in the subtle body, and while they originated and are often associated with the Eastern Hindu, Buddhist, and yogic traditions, western magical and energy workers can benefit from these powerful energy centers.


We will be discussing the different Chakras, their attributes, how one can use these points for their magical and healing purposes, and for those who wish to participate, we will do some energy moving exercises using these points.

Please bring a food or beverage item to share. Remember, we value your company more than anything else, so please don't worry if you don't feel like sharing, we would like to spend the evening with you regardless!

We are a donation based group so any contribution is appreciated.  Supplies, space, and website fees must be paid for, and your generous contributions help us grow and offer even better events in the future!

There will be a Dance lesson that starts at 7pm and the Dance will be from 8 to 11pm. There will be food available at the bar (hamburgers, hotdogs, pizza, buffalo wings, etc.) very reasonably priced. Bar will be open till 11pm. $10 cover includes Lesson and Dance. We will also be having a 50/50 drawing.  Meet new friends and have great night of dancing!!   Bowie Elks Lodge address: 1506 Defense Hwy. Gambrills, Md. 21054.  For any questions or info.  Please contact Dancin Dave at[masked] (leave message) or email  [masked]

results.description:
Hi all! 

We're lucky to have local author Erika Robuck join us for our next book club discussion!  Books are in the store this Thursday!  Support your local bookstore, peeps!  Make sure to pick your copy up here and hold onto your receipt for the event--snacks and light refreshments will be provided.  

Here are the details:

What: House of Hawthorne by Erika Robuck

When: Thursday, June 18th, 7PM

Where: The Bookstore, 35 Maryland Avenue

"Robuck pulls no punches in describing the tumult of such a passionate relationship. Sophia’s inner conflict between providing for her family and following her own creative desires is timely for anyone absorbed by Claire and Frank Underwood’s marital drama on Netflix’s House of Cards or for fans of Naomi Wood’s Mrs. Hemingway."—Booklist 

"Finding and giving voice to extraordinary women in the literary world is where Robuck’s talents lie…Will resonate with readers."—RT Book Reviews 

"Thoroughly engaging…Robuck has a light touch, and despite clocking in at 400 pages, the story flies by…A charming work."—Publishers Weekly

"[The House of Hawthorne] will have you transfixed."—People 


About the Author: Erika Robuck is a contributor to the fiction blog Writer Unboxed, and she maintains her own blog, Muse. She is a member of the Hawthorne Society, the Hemingway Society, the Historical Novel Society, and the Edna St. Vincent Millay Society. She lives in Annapolis, Maryland, with her husband and three sons. She is the author of Receive Me Falling, Hemingway's Girl, Call Me Zelda and Fallen Beauty.


Talk soon!

Jinny
results.name: The House of Hawthorne Book discussion with author Erika Robuck

results.description:
Free Reiki Share in Columbia, MD for people new to Reiki or experienced practitioners. This event is open to Reiki Practitioners as well as those simply curious about Reiki. Reiki practitioners of all levels of training, as well as all lineages, often enjoy the opportunity to participate in communal Reiki sessions known as Reiki Shares or Reiki Circles. The sessions give each person a chance to learn from one another as practitioners, as well as benefiting from multiple healing hands during the sessions. At this event we will take turns performing and receiving Reiki. Those that are not Reiki practitioners will be pared up with experienced Reiki practitioners. This is a fun event to be enjoyed by all. Please let me know in your response if you are new to Reiki or a practitioner of some level. For additional information please see

www.LastingLightReiki.com

7:15pm introduction for new attendees

results.description:
Friday at 7 AM will be 71 (feels like 74) and cloudy.  We've been asked for a 7:00 a.m. Meetup & here it is!  When it feels like eighty-two at ten we'll be glad we've already had our exercise.  Let's go and enjoy a walk with the doggies while it's still cool!  Please read directions below to find the Meeting Place:

Park at the Office Park parking lot on the other side of Brokenland Parkway from the dam end of Lake Elkhorn, Columbia, MD, 21046.  Please read the whole description below:


• Please go to the LAKEVIEW Office Park at 9821 Broken Land Parkway, Columbia, MD 21046.   Go to the driveway in front of the buildings and turn left.  Park by the edge of the woods.  Please take your dog out of the car, and look for people with dogs.  They will be looking for you & your dog too :)


•  If you are coming from Broken Land Parkway at the Columbia Mall direction, it is easier to turn into the Woodmere Office Park, at  9891 Broken Land Parkway, because it's at a traffic light, and you just turn right to get into it. (It's right across from Cradle Rock Pkwy. South.)  If you turn in here, drive toward the metal sculpture, then TURN LEFT.  Stay on this driveway, go through a stop sign, and continue driving, passing by all of the buildings on your right.  Keep driving all the way to the end, til you can't drive any further, and park at the edge of the WOODS.

• When you get out of the car, you should be able to see Lake Elkhorn from the parking lot.  The trailhead starts here at the edge of the woods, close to Broken Land Parkway.  This is where we will meet.  Please take your dog out and show him around so others will know they're in the right spot :) There is a tunnel that leads under Broken Land Parkway so we won't have to walk the dogs through traffic.  (The parking lot at the main entrance of the lake is too small to accomodate us, so we don't use the main entrance to the lake.)


• Please allow yourself time to arrive a few minutes BEFORE  the walk begins to allow the dogs to sniff each other and form their pack.  We will step off on time. We will turn right (counterclockwise) at the lake, so if you are late, and can run to catch us, turn right.  (Otherwise, if you're really late, turn left so you will run into us at some point and we can all walk together.)  If you cannot make it please change your RSVP in a timely manner, or leave a note in the comments section.  Thank you.


• Six foot length fixed leashes are required for your dog.  Retractable leashes are dangerous andcan amputate dogs' pawsif they become entwined in them, so let's keep the dogs' safety at heart.  Thank you.


                                                                Photos by J. Ameen-Lee

• If we stay over to the RIGHT we can avoid the runners and bikers.  Also, if you see a BIKE or a RUNNER coming towards us from either direction,please yell out "BIKE!" or "RUNNER!" or "ON YOUR LEFT!" so we can get our dogs safely to the RIGHT side to avoid them. Everyone else please echo the warning so the whole group hears it. (Especially important for dogs who like to leap toward runners or bikers.)  Thank you. 


• **Please bring water for your dog.**  It is important for your dog to have his own water supply to avoid communicable diseases.  We will take water stops and photo ops and have fun with the pups :)


Please read all the points below:

Columbia Dogs on the Go provides a way for friendly people with FRIENDLY DOGS (please, no snarling, growling, lunging or snapping dogs) to meet people with similar interests on a voluntary basis. By replying "Yes" to this RSVP and attending this event, you acknowledge that:

•  You are responsible for your own safety and the safety of your dogs and any guests. 

•  Your dogs are current on their vaccinations.

•  Your dogs will be kept on a leash (Fixed Length, non-retractable) and under your control at the Meetup.

•  You will clean up after your dogs at the Meetup.

•  You will update your RSVP if your plans change.

•  You understand that the Meetup ends when the walk ends. (If you choose to meet other members at a restaurant, dog park, or other location, it is on your own time and not part of the Meetup event.)

Looking forward to seeing you and your doggies there!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for a small silver car with "Tigerlily" plates, and a sable & white collie.
results.name: Let's enjoy the cool weather at Lake Elkhorn!

results.description:
7:00 AM is on the water time. Be sure to arrive early enough to get you kayak and gear ready. The plan is to get on the water and welcome L'Hermione as she enters Baltimore Harbor between 7:30 and 8:00AM. Then escort her (if we are permitted) to the Inner Harbor where she will dock next to the USS Constellation.

Pack a snack or lunch for yourself and be sure to bring plenty of water to stay hydrated. Wear non-cotton clothing, a hat, and sunscreen. We should be off the water before 11:00 AM.

For more information see : http://hermione2015.com/voyage2015/baltimore

Kayaking involves known and unanticipated risks including physical injury and death that cannot be eliminated without jeopardizing the essential quality of the sport. Group organizers and leaders and other members cannot pay continuous attention to all participants. Participants must be responsible for their own safety. Don’t overestimate your skills and abilities. Take instructional courses to learn about paddling technique, safety, self-rescue and hypothermia. Be aware of the tides, currents and weather conditions that will affect your safety on the days you paddle. Cooperate with group organizers, leaders and other members to insure your own safety as well as the safety of others and make it the fun, enjoyable day on the water it should be.
results.name: Welcome L’Hermione into Baltimore Harbor

results.description: This trip will take us to the Roan Mountain Balds, the greatest concentration of Balds in the World! As a bonus, we will enjoy the Rhododdendron in Bloom for one of the greatest displays in the United States! This is an 8 hour drive to the Northern NC/TN border to another one of those trips you have to do....before you die! You can find a description here: http://www.cs.unca.edu/nfsnc/recreation/roanmtn.pdf, here: http://www.romanticasheville.com/roan.htm, and a pretty picture here: http://wncnaturally.com/PhotosRoanMtn.html, so you can see this is a very special place! At Trail Days last month, the AT Through hikers told me, it was there favorite place and the rhododendron were not even blooming yet! We will start at Carver's Gap and walk 7 miles to Yellow Mountain Trail Shelter on the AT, ditch our packs and day hike on to Hump Mountain Balds, then back to the shelter, then backpack out again the next day...or if we are so overwhelmed can come back on Monday, depending on the group! Please be prepared to walk up to 21 miles total and 14 with a backpack on. You must also be prepared for rain and a great time! This is top flight summer backpacking, so saddle up, make that commitment and let's head down to Roan Mountain, on the NC/TN border!
results.name: Roan Mountain Balds and Blooming Rhododendron!

results.description: If you can only make one Happy Hour this year enjoy it, but if you can make two Happy Hours this year you don't want to miss this one! This is my 9th annual End of the Year, school year, happy hour, and last year was one of the best yet with over 150ppl joining us. This is an event shared with Charm City Social Club, and BNG meetups'. For years I did this at Bay Cafe, but last year we found out that Little Havana is just as much fun, they will again be giving us the side bar area as well as the outside area with its own seating and Corn Hole. So unlike previous years when the large group was spread out all over Bay Café we will have a more central location this year, so it will be easier to figure out who is with the group. For those who are worried about parking, free parking can be found in the lot to the left of Little Havana, next to Digital Harbor High School which is right down the street, and there is a parking garage next to the Rusty Scupper. I will be there around 4:30 for those who want to sneak out of work a little early, and be staying late for those who are stuck working. It should be a fun way to kick off the summer season, so I hope to see you all there..... Doug

Want to roleplay? This is your chance. We will have up to four GMs running different RPGs, often very fun ones you might not have heard of. This is a friendly and positive environment where everyone is welcome. 

Mountain Witch (run by Katie) is a game of trust and betrayal, set in 1960's Chicago. You're part of a team that's been assembled by a mysterious man to take out the Witch, the most feared mob boss in Chicago. But how much can you trust the people you're working with? results.description:
A Pathfinder Society Scenario designed for levels 3–7.

The Blakros family, long an ally of the Pathfinder Society, has come into possession of a manor house in the imperial nation of Cheliax, where a once prominent noble family was known to practice diabolism before the Age of Lost Omens. The Pathfinders' task is simple: clear the abandoned manor of any remaining threats before the Blakroses move in. Unfortunately, the estate hasn't sat empty as long as the Blakroses think it has, and its recent inhabitants were anything but the devil-worshipers who originally built the manor.

results.description:
"Networking On Purpose"We’ve already put a bug in your ear a few days ago around our upcoming BOND’s Business Meet & Greet Reception June 19th. Several of you have already added your names to the list. Well ladies, we’re finally able to release the official details of the evening’s festivities.  

You all are well aware that we are huge advocates for women owned businesses; you already know that we are passionate about the communities in which we live in, it goes without saying that we love empowering women, and not to mention we are in desperate need of a fun-filled evening to let our hair down, kick off our pumps and have a little fun in the process. Why not incorporate these elements for an evening of “Networking On Purpose”.

DETAILS
We’re rallying up women ran business owners, community leaders and advocates, socialites to build connections, to share ideas and to empower one another. You realize that we are far better together-than we are apart.
  When: Friday, June 19, 2015 at
Where: Union Mill- 1500 Union Avenue,  Baltimore, MD
Time: 7:30 PM- 9:30 PM
 
Did we mention that it’s FREE? Yes, it’s absolutely FREE to join us but we are requiring that you RSVP in advance.

NO, it won’t be your typical stuffy networking event

NO, you don’t have to be a BOND Member to attend

Yes, you can come alone but we are encouraging you to share this with your sister –friends

Yes, you will have a great time, it’s guaranteed

Of course, we’ll be doing a few giveaways 

WHAT SHOULD YOU BRING

20-30 hole punched business cards (if you don’t have a hole-punch not to worry we’ll have one available for you, just come with business cards)

Promotional or sample item for swag bags (items must be sent to Compass Consulting and Training Solutions, LLC at PO Box 421, Randallstown, MD 21133)

results.description:
Do you spend lots of time doing things that are really important to you, that spark joy, or that make great progress toward your biggest goals?

Or do you feel like most of your life is wasted away on activities and events that are not really creating much joy or success?

This book makes you realize that there's a big opportunity cost to everything you do.  

If you are filling your life with things that are just O.K., you’ll never have time or space to figure out what GREAT things would really make you happy.

Even though it doesn't cost money to watch TV, what it does cost to watch TV for three hours a day is three hours worth other activities like: exercise, spending time building relationships, planning, preparing etc - which could be the keys to creating great health, wealth and relationships in your life. 


What is the essential intent of your life?  

Which activities and efforts are in keeping with that intent, and which are you just doing by default....because everyone else is doing them, or they're easy?

____________________________

" An Essentialist produces more - brings forth more - by removing more instead of doing more." 


Are you always rushing in to help other people?  Then you'll love this quote: "Don't rob other people of their problems."  

The source of achievement and personal growth is having a problem to solve.  If you take away the problem, you take away all that too.

__________________________

By the time I got to the sixth chapter of this book, something in me clicked.  It was like my whole perspective on things had shifted. 

I started cancelling plans left and right - feeling great relief every time!

But then said YES! to other things with true clarity that this what what I really wanted. 

________________________

This books is a good continuation of the Magic of Tidying book we read a couple months ago. 

That book showed us that if it doesn’t spark joy - it shouldn't be in your home as then it’s just clutter that creates chaos and confusion for you mentally, emotionally and physically.


This book applies that theory to the rest of your life: if an activity or person doesn’t spark joy, say no!  

It takes courage to say no, doesn’t it.

_______________

For this next meeting, I’m going to keep us focused on the book and make sure everyone has equal time to share.

Please don't RSVP to this event unless you're going to read at least half of the book.   

I’m looking forward to hearing:

What you cut out of your life?

What you had the courage to so no to?

What would you really like to be doing?  

What activities really spark joy?

Hearing each other’s experiences will inspire us.  

I know Angela’s already started the book and it’s rocking her world a bit too.

Download the book here now! 

http://www.amazon.com/Essentialism-The-Disciplined-Pursuit-Less/dp/0804137382
results.how_to_find_us: I'll email you my address.
results.name: Discuss,  Essentialism: the disciplined pursuit of less, by Greg McKeown

We can bottom fish for Croakers and Spots from 7:00 AM to 3:00 PM aboard the Pennysaver.   We will need a total of 9 to keep the rate low. 

Bring bait (1 dz blood worms/shrimp), rod and reel, lunch, ice chest and something to drink. Be sure to wear a hat and bring sun screen. We are our own mates :-)

Theoria will collect the fee, $65 when we board.  Please bring exact change.

The carpool will meet at the WAWA on Rt 50 right before the Bay Bridge. 

Since we are meeting at a WAWA, please come a little early (around 5:00AM) if you want to purchase food, drinks or snacks or ice.   PLEASE NOTE THAT WE WILL LEAVE THE WAWA at 5:30 AM.  This will put us at the boat by 6:30 AM. 

One dozen should be sufficient.

Please let us know whether you are meeting us to carpool or going on your own. We may need extra drivers for the bridge so, if you are a bridge driver, please consider carpooling with us.  The toll is $6.

Here are directions to the WAWA: Exit 29A 321 Busch Frontage Road Annapolis, MD Take EXIT 29A toward MD-179/St Margaret's Rd/Busch's 0.2 mi.  Stay straight to go onto Busch's Frontage Rd. 0.06 mi 321 Busch Frontage Rd is on the right.  If you reach Saint Margaret's Rd you've gone about 0.3 miles too far. Take next exit to the service road and come back to WAWA.

We will leave WAWA and travel to the bait shop at exit 39B for blood worms.

If by any chance your plans change after you RSVP, YES, please change your response so that others can participate.  Thanking you in advance.

Welcome the summer sun and support LARS' work to end hunger and homelessness in the Laurel community. Celebrate the first day of summer and Father's Day weekend with family, friends, and neighbors. Enjoy great food, music, and post-race activities after challenging yourself to a 5K run throughout Old Towne Laurel or a 1 mile walk around the field.

If you have participated in LARS' Turkey Trot, the terrain will feel familiar with a few new challenges as we run a slightly modified (still USATF certified!) course... a great opportunity to get in shape for summer AND practice for next Thanksgiving!

Event details and schedule
Race day registration & check-in starts at 7:00AM at McCullough Field. Early check-in/packet pick up will be held at LARS on Friday, 6/19 (time TBA).

Warm-up begins at 7:40AM and the 5K run kicks off at 8:00AM. The 1 Mile Family Fun Walk begins at 8:05AM. Post-race activities, food, and prizes will follow at McCullough Field.

The 5K course takes runners through Historic Laurel and along the Patuxent River path. The 1 mile course is contained within McCullough Field.

Street parking is plentiful alongside the field and across Montgomery Street at the Laurel Boys & Girls Club.

Please be sure to sign the electronic waiver if registering online. Paper registration is available for download at www.laureladvocacy.org.

Follow LARS on Facebook for race updates and photos!

My contact phone number is[masked] please make sure you have it with you. This is in Pen Lucy off Coldspring and York Road just below Belvadere square. If you are using google maps you will need to put in 721 Mc Cabe for some reason. There is a wooden fence with a Habitat sign on it this is the meet up site across and down the street from 721.

NOTE*  We have been given a date of 6/20/2015 to volunteer with Habitat since they are full and are making space for our group.  More information will be posted a soon as I get a chance to add it on here.  There will be more dates given to volunteer after the 6/20/2015 date.  Cut off Date for RSVP'S will be June 10, 2015.  I must have all waivers and paper work in 1 week prior to our service day.  Please make sure you read the above literature enclosed so you get a full understanding of what we will be doing at the site.  This will make you day of volunteering more enjoyable.

I will be setting up more volunteer days once I get the dates from Habitat so others may volunteer.  I am limited by Habitat to 10 volunteers per volunteer date.  So please make sure that you can make the date you are signed up for.  If not please allow others to take your spot.  Cutoff to volunteer is 10 days before we have to volunteer and I must have 10 committed volunteers for that day.  Thanks for your understanding.

 Note * IF YOU SIGN UP FOR THIS YOU MUST PLAN ON A FULL DAY OF VOLUNTEERING. YOU ALSO MUST BE ABLE TO ATTEND ON THE DAY YOU SIGN UP FOR. I will be given a job or jobs that we will need to do on the given sign up day and since I am a Red Hat I will be over seeing the work is done in a safe manor.  I MUST HAVE EVERYONE'S EMAIL WHO SIGNS UP SO I MAY FORWARD YOU A WAIVER FORM FOR YOU TO FILL OUT AND SEND BACK BEFORE JUNE 10, 2015. Please send me you email address so I can attach a PDF waiver file to it.  I can not do it thru the meet up site.  My email is [masked].  Thanks

IF YOU CAN NOT ATTEND ON JUNE 20, 2015 PLEASE REMOVE YOURSELF FROM THE RSVP LIST SO OTHERS MAY ATTEND IN YOUR PLACE SINCE THIS IS EXTREMELY LIMITED TO THE NUMBER OF VOLUNTEERS THAT MAY ATTEND.

Things you will need to bring to the site on the day of volunteering;

1. Something to eat for lunch or money to get something for lunch.

2. Something to drink with your lunch.  Note * Habitat does provide a water cooler on site with paper cups to get a drink.

3. No open toes shoes.  Work boots or athletic shoes with slip-resistant and puncture-resistance rubber soles.

4. Old clothes that can get dirty or possibly stained. Work gloves if you need them.

5. A camera to capture your volunteer experience.

Habitat will provide;

1. Hard hats which must be worn at all times on the site.

2. Safety glasses which must be worn at all times on the site.

3. Habitat does have some work gloves on site, but it is recommend that you bring your own.

We want this to be a fun and fulfilling experience for all that come out and volunteer at the site. 

If you have any questions about volunteering and what will be involved you may contact me at [masked] so I can go into more detail.

Thanks,

Jim

results.description:
*** If you are attending this practice, please don't forget to sign up on our website by clicking the "Sign Up" link at the top. ***


The BDBC open practices occur every Wednesday from 6:15 to 7:30 PM and Saturday mornings from 8:00 to 9:00. For those of you that have never participated in dragon boating before, here are a few handy things to know to make your experience more enjoyable:

- The club has never flipped a boat during practice so the odds of you going completely into the water are very low but please keep in mind that there can be a significant amount of splashing on board. Chances are good that you will get a bit wet while we're out there so you should dress accordingly. Wear clothes that you won't mind getting wet in.

- As far as footwear goes, some people like to paddle barefoot, some like to wear flip flops and others like water shoes of some sort. Sneakers and shoes like that are usually a bad idea since they can get pretty wet and uncomfortable pretty quickly. - Although the club normally tries to have a cooler available with bottled water, it's not a bad idea to bring a bottle with you to practice to take on the boat. During the summer months especially, it can get pretty warm out there and we like to hydrate regularly.

- The seats on the boat are not the softest in the world and your butt will most likely be a bit sore after practice. To soften the seat a bit, it is recommended that you bring some sort of pad. There are many different options that our club members use and some of the most popular are gardening knee pads and folded up bath mats. A bunched up towel will suffice as well. - Other handy items that you may want to bring with you are sunglasses, sunscreen, gloves and a hat.

- Life jackets and paddles are provided to everyone.

- There is not room on the boat to bring much else with you so please leave everything in your car/on land.

- There is a secure waterproof bag available to collect everyone's car keys when we get on the boat.

- The point of our open practices, is to get people familiar with the sport of dragon boating while demonstrating proper technique and timing. Our coaches are excellent at explaining the mechanics of paddling a dragon boat and working towards the ultimate goal of having all twenty paddlers working as a single unit to move as efficiently through the water as possible, all while having a whole lot of fun! More information can be found at <a>www.baltimoredragonboatclub.com.</a> Hope to see you there!
results.name: Open Practice

results.description:
BPE MEMBERS! 

If you purchase a ticket or vendor table, I will thank you with a free hour of technical or business consulting!  But you must list WILL HOLMES as the one who referred you. 

DETAILS:

The Brothers of BPM cordially invite you to our 22nd Annual Rays of Hope Awards and Scholarship Breakfast.  The 2015 Rays of Hope Breakfast will be on June 20th at 9am at:

The Valley Mansion
594 Cranbrook Rd, Cockeysville, MD 21030

You can purchase tickets for $60 at https://www.eventbrite.com/e/22nd-annual-rays-of-hope-awards-and-scholarship-breakfast-tickets-16171121259

You can advertise your business and purchase a vendor table or purchase an ad in the Annual Book for $50 at https://www.eventbrite.com/e/22nd-annual-rays-of-hope-awards-and-scholarship-breakfast-tickets-16171121259

Here is the history of the event:

Nearly 400 people come together every June to honor the winners of Black Professional Men Inc.'s Rays of Hope Awards and Scholarships. The Rays of Hope Awards are given to outstanding African-American men who have excelled in their professions, and who serve as role models to younger Black men and boys. Awards are given in the categories of education, government, medicine, business, religion, and community and charitable services. Past winners include Congressman Elijah Cummings, Dr. Freeman Hrabowski, Ill, President of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, and Tuskegee Airmen Dr. Cyril Byron.

The Rays of Hope Breakfast is a time for Black Professional Men, Inc. to showcase its mentoring program, and to give scholarships to deserving Black male students from the Baltimore metropolitan area. In the past twenty years, Black Professional Men Inc. has awarded scholarships to more than 200 deserving African American male high school graduates. This year marks the 22nd anniversary of the Rays of Hope Breakfast. In honor of this momentous occasion, our goal is to award $1500 in scholarships, bringing our total scholarship giving over the past 21 years over $200,000.

In order to achieve this goal, and to celebrate twenty-one years of the event, we have planned a spectacular weekend of fun, informative, and inspiring events.  The Rays of Hope Awards and Scholarship Breakfast which will take place on Saturday, June 20, 2015 from 9:00 am to12:00 pm at Martin’s Valley Mansion. 

Purchase tickets, advertising or vending opportunities at:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/22nd-annual-rays-of-hope-awards-and-scholarship-breakfast-tickets-16171121259

DONT FORGET TO LIST ME AS THE MEMBER WHO REFERRED YOU!!!! 

-Will Holmes

results.description:
The Maryland Book Bank has provides new and gently used children's books to disadvantaged families in Baltimore. Their goal is to spark family reading at home by making sure there are plenty of books available.

Volunteers are needed to help organize books at the Book Bank. On days when the weather is favorable, volunteer organizers at the Book Bank often arrange for volunteers to work outdoors!

This event has been very popular with volunteers who work with children. An extra benefit of sorting books for the Maryland Book Bank is the nostalgia trip you'll experience when you see books that you just might remember from your childhood...!

For those who are interested, we may go to lunch at a nearby restaurant after this event.

How to find the warehouse:

The Book Bank is located at the rear entrance of The Baltimore Sun warehouse complex, where parking is available for all volunteers.

The Book Bank can be difficult to find, so be sure to follow the directions at

http://marylandbookbank.org/directions.html

The rear entrance on Guilford Road is a locked gate. In order to gain entrance, you will need to use the intercom on the left side of the gate and tell the guard that you're a volunteer for Maryland Book Bank.  In case the guard is not at the desk, we'll post a phone number for the Book Bank staff, who will come out to open the gate.

One of our volunteers has made a short YouTube video (about 1 minute in length) that might help you find the warehouse.  The video starts at the intersection of  N. Calvert St. and E. Centre St., goes through the back entrance gate on Guilford Ave, and ends at the door of the Book Bank warehouse.   This video can be found at http://youtu.be/I5cwEo_aKfQ .

results.description:
Saturday at 9:00 a.m. will be 70° Partly cloudy with 0% chance of rain. Let's grab the pups and visit the Hobbits in Hobbit's Glen!


We'll be in the shade almost 100% of this walk.  This is a paved trail, a mile in,  and a mile back, with several long gradual inclines (hills) (see photo below.)  Here is what a hiker said about the trail:  "It was a great walk! Glad I am in condition walking over 20 miles a week! Those hills were humdingers!" (R.Maretsky)  So if you are cardiovascularly challenged, or out of shape, please try to build up your stamina before you go on this hike with us.  It is among the top three trails in length that we use, surpassed by Centennial Lake, and the Green Trail in Savage Park/Wincopin Trails, and more strenuous due to the numerous elevation changes.

• Directions:  Take Cedar Lane to Harper's Farms Road and turn left.   Go around half a mile.

• Go to Willow Bottom Road and turn left.  (It's the first REAL road left turn, passing by 'Woodlot' which is a dead end.)

WHERE TO MEET

• Go to the Hobbit's Glen Golf Course parking lot.  Turn in the lot, go left toward the trees in the left corner closest to the entrance.  Take your doggy out of the car :) 


• Parade your dog around so folks will know they're in the right spot.  We will meet there by the trees in the shade.  When you go beyond the parking lot, you should be able to look down a hill onto the street below (Willow Bottom Rd.)

• Please make an effort to arrive early as we will step off ON TIME.  It WILL BE HARD TO FIND US IF YOU ARRIVE LATE, as we will go to Ivy Bush Lane and take a right into a fairly hidden paved trail. Please change your RSVP in a timely manner if you are not going to attend.

SAFETY

• SIX FOOT FIXED LEASHES ARE REQUIRED for your dogs, for your dogs' safety and other walkers' safety. Retractable leashes can amputate dogs' paws. Thank you for keeping our pooches' safety at heart.

•** Please bring water for your dog, as this is a two mile hike with long hills.  The weather is warm, so your dogs will need to stay hydrated.**


• There may be others on the trail running or on bikes.  Keep a watch for them, try to stay to the right of the path, and yell out "ON YOUR LEFT!" loud enough to be heard by talking walkers to prevent our dogs getting run over by running or biking humans.


• PLEASE READ:


Columbia Dogs on the Go provides a way for friendly people with friendly dogs to meet on a voluntary basis. By replying "Yes" to this RSVP and attending this event, you acknowledge that:


•  You are responsible for your own safety and the safety of your dogs and any guests. 

•  Your dogs are current on their vaccinations.

•  Your dogs will be kept on a leash (non-retractable) and under your control at the Meetup.

•  You will clean up after your dogs at the Meetup.

•  You will update your RSVP if your plans change.

•  You understand that the Meetup ends when the walk ends. (If you choose to meet other members at a restaurant, dog park, or other location, it is on your own time and not part of the Meetup event.)

Looking forward to seeing you there!

                                                                        Photos by J. Ameen-Lee
results.how_to_find_us: Go to the left all the way over to the trees in the parking lot in the shade overlooking the hill -we will meet there.
results.name: Let's enjoy a cool, shady walk at Hobbit's Glen!

results.description:
Come out for a trail run in Patapsco Valley State Park, Glen Artney area, near Catonsville and Halethorpe.

These trails are technical and challenging with several steep climbs, rocks, roots, loose dirt, and uneven surfaces.  To make up for all of the hard stuff, there is also a good amount of flat and downhill sections.  We’ll also be sharing the trails with mountain bikers, hikers, and other runners.  

Route Description:

The plan is a ~5.6 mi run: along Soapstone, Vineyard Spring, Grist Mill, Nunnery, Santee Branch, and Soapstone back out. We can also hit the Bull Run trail for another good climb and extra mile.


The route has several hills and climbs, creek crossings, and a bit of asphalt running. Most of the trail is wooded and there are bathrooms and water fountains mid-way. There will be some water crossing, dirt and muddy areas, rocks, and sticks...so please wear shoes you don't mind getting dirty or wet.  

GPS map of the route:

https://connect.garmin.com/modern/activity/565204424


Parking:

Parking is available at the Park and Ride in Catonsville (intersection of Rolling Road/MD 166 and 195) or at the trail head (just across the street).  We will meet up at the trail head, look for the group of runners.

Hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: We will gather at the trail head (across Rolling Rd. from the Park and Ride)
results.name: Trail Run - Patapsco Soapstone (Catonsville area)

results.description:
After losing chieftain after chieftain, the Birdcruncher goblin tribe finally found competent leadership in its four goblin "heroes"—Reta Bigbad the fighter, Chuffy Lickwound the rogue, Poog the cleric of Zarongel, and Mogmurch the alchemist. But it turns out leading a tribe of goblins isn't much fun, and the newest Birdcruncher chieftains are bored. In order to cure their doldrums, the chieftains have issued a new demand—find them some adventure, or else!

Eager to please their great chieftains, the Birdcruncher goblins frantically try to whip up all sorts of amusements, including goblin games, feats of skill, and a grand feast. But trouble arises in the midst of the goblins' feast for their mighty leaders—the goblins who went to harvest truffles for the feast got beat up by some stinky humans!

Now the Birdcruncher chieftains find themselves getting more adventure than they bargained for as they venture to the Bestest Truffle Field to pick up the slack for their bumbling minions. Will the goblin heroes be able to make it to the field, find the treasured fungus, defeat the mean humans, and make it back to the tribe in time to enjoy their well-deserved feast?

We Be Goblins Free! is an adventure for four 4th-level goblin characters, written for the award-winning Pathfinder Roleplaying Game. The adventure takes place near the Devil's Platter in Varisia in the Pathfinder campaign setting, and serves as a sequel to both We Be Goblins! and We Be Goblins Too!, Paizo's popular 2011 and 2013 Free RPG Day adventures!
results.name: Free RPG Day Module - We Be Goblins Free!

results.description:
Welcome to Warrior Meditation!  

 These meditation sessions are non-secular and available to anyone wishing to meditate.   All experience levels are welcome. 

During this session, I'll be offering 4 rounds 10 to 15 minutes of Shamatha Meditation (also known as Calm Abiding, or Mindfulness meditation).   I have been practicing this form of meditation since 1990, and learned the technique in the Nyingma School of Tibetan Buddhism.   

 Each session will consist of instruction in the meditation technique, meditation rounds, and a free form discussion following. This is designed for anyone who wishes to learn/practice Calm Abiding meditation. Once this technique is mastered, we can begin work on the techniques of Insight Meditation as well!

Cheers!
Terri

results.description:
INFORMATION
WHAT:
The festival is a celebration of African American life, music and culture. This family-oriented event is filled with celebrity artists and entertainers, children’s activities, arts, history, education, financial literacy, health & wellness and more. The African American Festival is presented by Black Enterprise, hosted by Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake and the City of Baltimore, and produced by greiBO Entertainment with the support of the advisory board and steering committee.


WHEN:
June 20-21, 2015

WHERE:
Camden Yards Sports Complex
on Lots B and C between Oriole Park at Camden Yards and M&T Bank stadium
1101 Russell Street, Baltimore, MD 21230

FAQS
WHEN IS THE 2015 AFRICAN AMERICAN FESTIVAL?
The festival dates/times are as follows:
Saturday – June 20th, 2015 (noon – 10pm)
Sunday – June 21st, 2015 (noon – 8pm)

WHERE DOES THE FESTIVAL TAKE PLACE?
The festival will take place at Camden Yards Sports Complex on lots B and C between Oriole Park at Camden Yards and M&T Bank stadium, 1101 Russell Street, Baltimore, MD 21230

HOW MUCH DOES IT COST TO ATTEND THE FESTIVAL THIS YEAR?
The festival is FREE!!

WHAT CAN I EXPECT AT THE FESTIVAL?
The 2015 African American Festival offers something for everyone with an extensive selection of entertainment, cultural exhibits, contests, health screenings, education and financial empowerment activities. Visit more than 150 vending booths and attractions as well as enjoy 2 stages of entertainment during the 2-day celebration.

ARE THERE ACTIVITIES FOR CHILDREN AT THE FESTIVAL?
Yes, there are several activities for children including youth performances, arts & crafts, inflatable obstacle courses and a rock climbing wall.

HOW CAN I PARTICIPATE IN THE FESTIVAL?
There are several ways you can participate in the 2015 African American Festival. You can Sponsor, be a vendor or volunteer. Visit the corresponding sections of the website for detailed information.

HOW CAN I BECOME A VENDOR AT THE FESTIVAL?
To get info on becoming a vendor, please go to the Vendors section of the website to download an application form and read all vendor related info. Applications will be accepted until all booth spaces have been filled. For additional information send an email to [masked] or call Va’sama Williams at[masked]-8861.

WHERE CAN I GET ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS THAT ARE NOT ADDRESSED ON THIS SITE?
For additional questions, please contact the Event Producer, greiBO media at[masked] or [masked].

This is a no host event.  Any additional questions contact the event venue and not the Meetup organizer.

Thanks!
results.how_to_find_us: This is a no host event - guests will attend on their own
results.name: FYI - No Host Event: The 2015 African American Festival - Baltimore (Free)

The twenty-first century is when everything changes. And you've got to be ready.

 

 

The Doctor Is In!  If you think "Fezzes are cool!" then this is the Discussion Meetup for you!

What? What? What?:

Dr. Who Discussion Meetup!

Where in the Whoniverse:

“Somewhere there’s danger, somewhere there’s injustice, somewhere else, the tea’s getting cold.”  and that place is Amazing Spiral: Books, Comics, Toys & More!

When:  January 24th from  12pm - 2pm  (come for whatever part you can, often people come at 12 or at 1 and leave and stay as their schedule allows).[Note: This is a time change from 2014, when we met from 1 -3pm]  Then every third Saturday from 12 to 2pm for 2015.  Please call Amazing Spiral if there is inclement weather to see if the group is meeting or not. Amazing Spiral[masked]

Topics: January - The Christmas Episode is on the agenda.  What is the regular agenda? Er..."I will explain later..."  But we are getting a projector that can be hooked up to a computer, so viewing "Stuff" will be on it!

Who: The Doctor is In!   Dr. Anthony Spencer, Heather Schneider and Driana Pearlman have all stepped into the Tardis to lead our erstwhile group.  We know this because we built the Tardis as part of Dr. Who Day on July 26th, 2014.  Having the Power of Three means that we will never have to cancel the group for lack of moderator!!!!!

Why:

"The twenty-first century is when everything changes. And you've got to be ready."

and because we all need a little (or a lot) more Who in our lives!

How:

In costume is welcome!

Don't worry if you have only seen a few episodes, even if those episodes were decades ago!  As long as you have an interest in Talking Who Talk then you are ready!

Please check out Doctor Who Anonymous on Meet up for more cool Who-Peeps!

 

Look for Spider-Man to find Amazing Spiral: Books, Comics, Toys, GAMES & More!

We are across from the Senator Theater and around the corner from Belvedere Square Market Shops.

Ample parking in the back and on the street.
results.how_to_find_us: We are across from the re-Opened Senator Theatre.  Look for Spider-Man! Parking in the back and on the street.

results.description:
After losing chieftain after chieftain, the Birdcruncher goblin tribe finally found competent leadership in its four goblin "heroes"—Reta Bigbad the fighter, Chuffy Lickwound the rogue, Poog the cleric of Zarongel, and Mogmurch the alchemist. But it turns out leading a tribe of goblins isn't much fun, and the newest Birdcruncher chieftains are bored. In order to cure their doldrums, the chieftains have issued a new demand—find them some adventure, or else!

Eager to please their great chieftains, the Birdcruncher goblins frantically try to whip up all sorts of amusements, including goblin games, feats of skill, and a grand feast. But trouble arises in the midst of the goblins' feast for their mighty leaders—the goblins who went to harvest truffles for the feast got beat up by some stinky humans!

Now the Birdcruncher chieftains find themselves getting more adventure than they bargained for as they venture to the Bestest Truffle Field to pick up the slack for their bumbling minions. Will the goblin heroes be able to make it to the field, find the treasured fungus, defeat the mean humans, and make it back to the tribe in time to enjoy their well-deserved feast?

We Be Goblins Free! is an adventure for four 4th-level goblin characters, written for the award-winning Pathfinder Roleplaying Game. The adventure takes place near the Devil's Platter in Varisia in the Pathfinder campaign setting, and serves as a sequel to both We Be Goblins! and We Be Goblins Too!, Paizo's popular 2011 and 2013 Free RPG Day adventures!
results.name: Free RPG Day Module:  We Be Goblins Free!

results.description:
The Licktoads, once the great and fierce goblin tribe in Brinestump Marsh, were defeated by human adventurers! All that remains of the tribe are its four goblin "heroes"—Reta Bigbad the fighter, Chuffy Lickwound the rogue, Poog the cleric of Zarongel, and Mogmurch the alchemist. Homeless and bored, they left their swampy homeland to join the neighboring goblin tribe, the Birdcrunchers.

The good news is that the Birdcrunchers are willing to let the goblin heroes join their tribe.

The better news is that the Birdcrunchers have heard of these four, and want one of them to become their new chieftain.

The bad news is that before the goblins can join, they'll need to endure a series of dangerous and humiliating tests. Very dangerous. Very humiliating.

The worse news is that lately Birdcruncher chieftains have had really short lifespans—they're being killed by the pet fire-breathing boar of a local ogre who wants the Birdcruncher land as his own.

Can the four heroes of the now-dead Licktoad tribe save the Birdcrunchers and, in so doing, become their new leaders?
results.name: We Be Goblins Too!
